newsitem.title: INDIA: India's oil bill not seen hit immediately by Iraq.
newsitem.headline: India's oil bill not seen hit immediately by Iraq.

text.p: Strengthening oil prices following U.S. missile attacks on Iraq are not expected to hurt India's import bills for crude and products immediately, petroleum officials said on Wednesday.
But they said the petroleum ministry was assessing the longer-term impact of rising prices on imports. This was unlikely to become clear for at least several days.
"At the moment, there are no problems on the oil supplies. The imports necessary for September have already been contracted," one official quoted Vijay Kelkar, secretary in the ministry, as saying.
"We have a comfortable stock of products and crude oil," the official told Reuters.

India's annual oil import demand of some 22 to 23 million tonnes of crude and 16 million tonnes of refined products cost around $6.5 billion last year. This accounted for around 20 to 22 percent of the country's total import bill.
Officials said India bought much of its crude and products from the Middle East but gave no breakdown.
The U.S. launched a second wave of missiles against military targets in southern Iraq on Wednesday in retaliation for Iraqi military intervention in the country's Kurdish north.
India's oil pool deficit, effectively the net subsidy for petroleum products, for the year to next March 31 is 55 to 60 billion rupees ($1.54 billion to 1.68 billion).

On the longer-term impact of developments in Iraq, an Indian Oil Corp (IOC) official said: "The (long-term) impact cannot be assessed at the moment. Only in the next few days can the trends be ascertained."
The IOC is the sole agent for imports of crude oil.
"India will be floating tenders for October POL (Petroleum Oil and Lubricants), buying only in late September. Buyings for September have already been firmed up," one ministry official said.
He said the government was keeping a close watch on the supply situation and monitoring the market.
India buys product both on spot markets as well as term contracts, while crude is largely purchased on term.

"Every one dollar increase in oil price will lead to additional payment of about $340 million a year by India, which will go out of the oil pool account," said P. Dhileepan, an analyst at Crosby Ltd, a securities company.
This would mean an impact of $180 million for the remaining seven months of the current fiscal year ending next March, presuming price increases were maintained, he said.
Dhileepan estimated the oil pool deficit would widen to around 56 billion rupees from the current 50 billion rupees under this scenario.

Rajendra Pachauri, of Tata Energy Research Institute, an independent think-tank, said: "I don't think it (the U.S. action) will have much of impact, maybe one billion rupees if it lasts two or three weeks."
He said India had made sizeable oil purchases in recent weeks and did not have to rush for more.
"We should really play it cool," he said. "The scenario is not alarming."
